clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy Study of Vitamin D and Statins to Treat Hypercholesterolemia
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Vitamin D and Statins on Plasma Lipid Profiles in Chinese Patients With Hypercholesterolemia

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators planned to research the effect of vitamin D supplementation as an adjuvant therapy for patients with hypercholesterolemia.

detailed_description.textblock: Vitamin D is primarily generated in the skin, in response to direct absorption of ultraviolet B radiation. Vitamin D can also be obtained through fortified foods and oral supplements. Lipid abnormalities are common in the general population, and are regarded as a modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Recently low vitamin D status has been shown to be associated with increased risk of developing hyperlipidemia. Statins are normally the first-line therapy for hypercholesterolemia. It is also reported that vitamin D can improve serum lipid levels. However, its effects on hypercholesterolemia patients remain unclear. The investigators planned to determine the efficacy of combination therapy with statins and vitamin D in a cohort of hypercholesterolemia patients. This study may shed light as to whether oral vitamin D supplementation can be an adjunct therapy in hypercholesterolemia patients.

primary_outcome.measure: a change in serum total cholesterol level
primary_outcome.time_frame: after 6 months of vitamin D supplementation
primary_outcome.description: The primary end point was a change in serum total cholesterol level after 6 months of vitamin D supplementation.

secondary_outcome.measure: a change in serum triglycerides level
secondary_outcome.time_frame: after 6 months of vitamin D supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: The change in serum triglycerides level was measured after 6 months of vitamin D supplementation.

secondary_outcome.measure: differences in the incidences of treatment-emergent adverse events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: after 6 months of vitamin D supplementation
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs): hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, constipation

arm_group.description: drug: vitamin D3 tablets (Vigantoletten; Merck Pharma, Germany); the frequency: 2000 IU vitamin D3 tablets were taken daily; duration: 6 months.
drug: placebo tablets; the frequency: 2000 IU placebo tablets were taken daily; duration: 6 months.

intervention.description: 2000 IU vitamin D3 tablets were taken daily for 6 months
2000 IU placebo tablets were taken daily for 6 months

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
The main inclusion criteria were for hypercholesterolemia patients with the treatment of statins.
Exclusion Criteria:
The exclusion criteria were as follows: patients with chronic renal failure, chronic liver disease, bone disorders, and/or thyroid disorders. Patients were also excluded if they were taking vitamin D3 tablets or other lipid-regulating drugs.
